Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the idea that China and India got away "scot-free" and didn't have to take any steps until 2030. In reality, both China and India have pledged to take steps to meet emission reduction goals by 2030 as part of the Paris Accord.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up the assertion that China and India got away without any consequences. It does not provide any evidence or data to support this claim.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that both China and India have made commitments to reduce emissions by 2030 as part of the Paris Accord.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the Paris Accord was a bad deal solely because China and India did not have to take immediate steps. However, it fails to consider other aspects of the agreement and the contributions of other countries.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for why China and India were given until 2030 to take steps. It does not take into account factors such as their population size, historical emissions, or other considerations that may have influenced the agreement.
